(9/9) The question is not if but when the next public health emergency will come. Our goal & our obligation as policymakers is to make sure that we are ready for it.

Thank you to everyone involved in today‚Äôs proceeding ‚Äì the conversation was productive and thoughtful.

(8/ ) Dr. Aragon stressed the importance of: 
- Regular & timely communication
- A single & consistent point of contact for local officials
- Data monitoring
- Expansive testing 
- Community engagement
- Behavioral health resources
- Public health infrastructure investments

(7/ ) Our final panel will look ahead to statewide readiness and response.
- Dr. Tom√°s Arag√≥n, State Public Health Officer & Director of @CAPublicHealth
- Stephanie Welch, Deputy Secretary of Behavioral Health of @Cal_HHS
- Mitch Medigovich, Deputy Director of @Cal_OES

(6/ ) Dr. Kelley highlights the importance of bolstering CA's healthcare workforce b4 the next public health emergency: ‚ÄúW/o a workforce, we will be in a worse place when the next pandemic hits." Dr. Sisson adds that loan repayment & competitive salaries will aid in this effort.

@providence @ochealth @YoloCountyHHSA (5/ ) Takeaways from Dr. Sisson:
1. We cannot continue business as usual
2. Clear and transparent communication is critical
3. We must invest in our public health workforce
4. Equity cannot be an afterthought

(4/ ) Panel 2 will explore lessons learned from unique perspectives on the frontlines.
- Laura Ramos, Chief Exec of @providence St. Jude Medical Center
- Dr. Veronica Kelley, Chief of Mental Health & Recovery Services, @ochealth
- Dr. Aimee Sisson, Health Officer, @YoloCountyHHSA

(3/ ) "You can't respond to something that you don't know about. What we have to do is much more in the way of creative imagination - to imagine what the future will be like w/ infectious diseases. It starts w/ discussions like the one we are having right now..." - @mtosterholm

(2/ ) We are starting off with an overview of CA's response to COVID-19 and takeaways from the pandemic. Joining us are Dr. @mtosterholm, Director of @CIDRAP, & Professor Rich Callahan, Co-Director of the @usfca Master of Public Health Program.

and that the observance of Columbus Day is a way of sanitizing the broader imperial & colonial sins of Native Americans. Indigenous People‚Äôs Day was first instituted in California in Berkeley in 1992, to coincide with the 500th anniversary of the arrival of Christopher Columbus.
In recent years, a movement has arisen which rejects celebrating Columbus, asserting that such an honor represents "the violent history of the colonization in the Western Hemisphere",

Indigenous People‚Äôs Day started as a counter-celebration to Columbus Day, which remains a federal holiday, and which honors Italian explorer Christopher Columbus who, ironically, never actually set foot in what we now know as America.

Like Columbus Day‚Äîindeed, because of Columbus Day‚Äî#IndigenousPeoplesDay is observed across the United States on the second Monday of October, and is an official city and state holiday in a range of localities.

Today is, depending on which way you look, both Columbus Day and #IndigenousPeoplesDay2020.  Indigenous Peoples' Day celebrates and honors the Native American peoples, their histories, and their cultures. https://t.co/gCB3L1YTfO

for this election cycle I had to make the difficult decision to decline the spending, and unfortunately, this means I wasn‚Äôt eligible to have a ballot statement included in the Voter Guide.

So even though I‚Äôm totally supportive of campaign finance reform and lowering the barriers to political participation in every way possible, in order to have even a remote chance of competing on a level playing field...

and most likely, directly against me-- by Big Oil and some of the same special interests who previously bankrolled the recall campaign against me. On our side, I won‚Äôt have the luxury of similar support

In my race, my opponent accepted the limit, and so has a ballot statement in the Voter Guide, but is also assured of literally millions of dollars of additional support and spending on behalf of her campaign...
$1.3 million might seem like a lot of money (and it is), but not all campaigns play by the same rules.

A candidate who commits to that limit not only has the option of having his or her ballot statement included in the Voter Guide, he or she is also subject to fines and even criminal prosecution if they commit to the limit and then exceed it during over the course of a campaign.
The limit, which is adjusted each cycle, is currently just over $1.3 million for this year‚Äôs #GeneralElection.
Under a #California statute created by the passage of Proposition 34 in 2000, in order to have a ballot statement in the Voter‚Äôs Guide, candidates have to commit to voluntary fundraising limits.

That speech has stayed with me ever since, and not just because multiple people in the audience passed out during his remarks from the intense heat (by the end of it, people were dropping like flies) but because of the power of his presence and the impact of his words.
After the usual introductions and encomiums, he spoke for well over an hour, under a blazing sun and no shade and with the temperature well into the 90s.

I actually had the honor of meeting Nelson Mandela in person. It was the summer of 1992, at a luncheon held in his honor on the grounds of Gracie Mansion as part of the proceedings Democratic National Convention in New York City that year.

Nelson Mandela was known for his unwavering dignity and an unbreakable will, which allowed him to absorb years of imprisonment and abuse as a prelude to ultimately assuming the leadership of a South Africa in transition and presiding with magnanimity, compassion, and mercy.

Today is Nelson Mandela International Day, also known as Mandela Day, held on July 18 each year to commemorate Nelson Mandela's achievements in working towards conflict resolution, democracy, human rights, peace, and reconciliation. https://t.co/oY8y3S34mU
His clarion voice, which will be sorely missed, will continue to inspire future generations, daring them to be as courageous, as committed, and as kind.
For those who worked with him, he was the conscience of the US Congress, a vocal, passionate, and relentless advocate and exemplar of equality and positive change.

Congressman John Lewis was the son of a Georgia sharecropper who rose, by strength of character and sheer force of will, to become a generational leader in the fight for justice, first as a Freedom Rider and then as a member of the US House of Representatives.

As discussed yesterday, one of the two benchmarks established by the Governor earlier this week as thresholds for relaxing restrictions was a countywide requirement for the number of new cases in the past two weeks to be less than 25 per hundred thousand residents.

Meanwhile, we all continue to find ourselves wondering, ‚ÄúAre things getting better, worse, or are we stuck in some kind of Ground Hog-day cycle with no endpoint?‚Äù Nobody seems to know for sure at the moment, an unnerving thing in its own right. We all deserve better.

I‚Äôve had some good suggestions recently about how to track and present some of the district-related indicators differently, like cases per 100,000 or on a rolling multi-day average. Going to try and incorporate some of those suggestions starting next week.

Each of those counties reports their COVID numbers in different formats, so that it hasn‚Äôt been possible so far to correlate things like hospitalizations, ICU beds occupied, or even COVID-related deaths for SD-29 as a whole or for each of the individual cities.
The data used for these daily reports is, as I‚Äôve mentioned before, the numbers of confirmed cases in each of the cities whose borders fall within  SD-29, which straddles three separate counties.
that much of the new testing is yielding results that are less than 100% accurate, raising further questions about the quality of the data being provided to us.

On the one hand, that‚Äôs a good thing, and we‚Äôll all happily take good news where we find it; on the other, it‚Äôs not altogether reassuring to see evidence of what has been the subject of recent reporting:

Today‚Äôs numbers are also noteworthy in that it‚Äôs the first time in recent memory that there were changes to the numbers of all of the 16 cities in the district. The totals for two of them‚ÄîIndustry and La Habra‚Äîwere downward adjustments.
That‚Äôs a continuation of an alarming spike in newly reported cases over the past three days, with 214 new cases in SD-29 and 107 new cases in Anaheim alone in that span.
